unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Construction of a Type of Mean interval : Who Gets Paid More?
question_text:
You have probably heard that men are typically paid more than women for the same type of job. A researcher wanted to investigate this claim. Using information from a census, the researcher randomly selected $10$ occupations and looked at the median salary (in dollars) for men and women from each occupation. The median salaries per occupation and the differences (man-woman) are given in the table below. Each occupation is listed as a letter.

Which of the following represents a $90\%$ confidence interval for the average difference in the median prices per occupation between men and women?
solution:
To solve for this, you must first realize this is paired data and not two-sample. The data is paired by occupation, meaning there is a man and woman that goes to each occupation.

This is also a $t$-interval, since the population standard deviation is unknown and we are using a sample standard deviation. Remember the mnemonic Mr. T is mean.

A paired $t$-interval for means is run the same way as a one-sample $t$-interval for means. In this case, we use the differences (data from row 3) of each occupation for data. Put that data into your calculator and run the $t$-interval, or you could do the work out by hand.

If you have TI-84:

Enter the data in L1
Go to Stat
Go to Test
Select T-interval
Select Data and L1
Change the level to .90
Calculate

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'B' is incorrect, as that is the answer for a paired $z$-interval for means.

Choice 'C' is incorrect, as that is the answer for a two sample $t$-interval for means.

Choice 'D' is incorrect, as that is the answer for a two sample $z$-interval for means.

Choice 'E' is incorrect, as this answer comes from the minimum difference and maximum difference of the occupations.
